summary: One case of suspected polio, 24 cases of suspected Hepatitis A and one case of hemorrhagic fever have been registered in Kosovo. "These are the first cases registered" in Kosovo since the end of the NATO bombing, WHO says. The reader assumes all risks in using information posted by ProMED-mail.

5 cases of Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) in Kosovo region of Yugoslavia, all around the city of Pristina. Two of the cases have been "confirmed" 16 reports of CCHF so far this year, originating from Russia, Central Asia, South Africa and Middle East.

Cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever are not particularly unexpected in this region. The single confirmed case recorded in Malisevo this year has not yet been notified. The figures for the last five years are as follows: 1995 - 119 cases, 16 fatal in Peja 68/9; 1996 - 23 cases, 5 fatal inPeja 9/2; 1997 - 8 cases, none fatal; 1998 - one case; 1999 - 7 cases, two fatal; 2000 - 4 cases.

Cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever are not particularly unexpected in this region. The single confirmed case recorded in Malisevo this year has not yet been notified. The figures for the last five years are as follows: 1995 - 119 cases, 16 fatal in Peja 68/9; 1996 - 23 cases, 5 fatal inPeja 9/2; 1997 - 8 cases, none fatal; 1998 - one case; 1999 - 7 cases, two fatal; 2000 - 4 cases.

Cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever are not particularly unexpected in this region. The single confirmed case recorded in Malisevo this year has not yet been notified. The figures for the last five years are as follows: 1995 - 119 cases, 16 fatal in Peja 68/9; 1996 - 23 cases, 5 fatal inPeja 9/2; 1997 - 8 cases, none fatal; 1998 - one case; 1999 - 7 cases, two fatal; 2000 - 4 cases.

Cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever are not particularly unexpected in this region. The single confirmed case recorded in Malisevo this year has not yet been notified. The figures for the last five years are as follows: 1995 - 119 cases, 16 fatal in Peja 68/9; 1996 - 23 cases, 5 fatal inPeja 9/2; 1997 - 8 cases, none fatal; 1998 - one case; 1999 - 7 cases, two fatal; 2000 - 4 cases.

Cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever are not particularly unexpected in this region. The single confirmed case recorded in Malisevo this year has not yet been notified. The figures for the last five years are as follows: 1995 - 119 cases, 16 fatal in Peja 68/9; 1996 - 23 cases, 5 fatal inPeja 9/2; 1997 - 8 cases, none fatal; 1998 - one case; 1999 - 7 cases, two fatal; 2000 - 4 cases.

Cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever are not particularly unexpected in this region. The single confirmed case recorded in Malisevo this year has not yet been notified. The figures for the last five years are as follows: 1995 - 119 cases, 16 fatal in Peja 68/9; 1996 - 23 cases, 5 fatal inPeja 9/2; 1997 - 8 cases, none fatal; 1998 - one case; 1999 - 7 cases, two fatal; 2000 - 4 cases.

Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) in Kosovo -- WHO Update 2. 44 case alerts have been notified to the Kosovo health authorities. Of these, 12 have been confirmed, and 16 have been found negative for CCHF. A further 16 are currently under investigation.

A ProMED-mail post is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases. WHO has reported 69 suspected cases of Crimean-Congo Haemorrhagic Fever in Kosovo. Of these, 18 are confirmed as Crimean-congo fever (CCHF); 15 by laboratory diagnosis.

4 new cases of suspected haemorrhagic fever reported in Prizren, Serbia. Overall number of persons suspected of having contracted the disease reaches 19. 3 of the confirmed cases were confirmed in Ljubljana, Slovenia. Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever is a severe tick-borne disease.

CCHF is spread from birds and livestock to man by tick bite, and has a 50% mortality rate. We are seeing a fair amount of CCHF in Balochistan, which is proving to beinteresting. We have at least two other cases now serologically confirmed, and we are proposing to set up surveillance in Quetta.

Four cases of Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever have been diagnosed in Pakistan. The four cases belonged to the same family of herders living in close contact with their sheep. The reader assumes all risks in using information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. The accuracy and completeness of the information posted is not guaranteed.

In December 1994 in a private hospital in Quetta, Pakistan, 3 health-workers contracted Crimean-Congo Haemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) after actively bleeding patient who later died. Two of 4 people exposed percutaneously, i.e. blood crossing breached skin, contracted CCHF, and 1 of 5 with cutaneous exposure,.i. blood touching intact skin. No anti-C CHF antibodies or cases among persons who had body fluids other than blood contact skin.

A patient from Baluchistan, and a male nursing assistant attending the patient, died on Fri 3 Nov 2000 in the Aga Khan Private Hospital. The disease was confirmed as Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) after blood samples were sent to the Centers for Disease Control in the United States. CCHF was first detected in Crimea in 1944 and again in Congo in 1956.

A new case of Congo-Crimean hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has been admitted to Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre (JPMC) The patient has been moved to an isolation ward in the Medical Intensive Care Unit (ICU) to prevent other patients from contracting the viral infection. So far 14 CCHF patients had been brought to the hospital, and 5 of them had died. 10 people have died at various Karachi hospitals because of CCHf this year.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever has reportedly hit northern parts of Pakistan. 2 nurses at the Shifa International Hospital were found to be suffering from the same disease. The disease originated in Africa in 1967 and is still common there. A doctor at the hospital said there was no chance of an epidemic spreading in Islamabad.

Deaths in Islamabad and Peshawar Confirmed as Cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) 2 people who died in Pakistan and whose blood samples had been sent to the NIV were victims of CCHF. The NIH had sent the blood samples of the 3, which confirmed 3, that the [s from the 2 deceased patients were that the virus-positive]. It, however, was not available for confirmation of the virus.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever is suspected in Pakistan. 2 people have died and 4 more are fighting for their lives in Quetta. The same acute hemorrhagic fever claimed 18 lives in Baluchistan late last year.Laboratory confirmation is lacking; the diagnosis appears to be lacking.

Only 35 cases of the virus have been reported in the Pakistani-Afghan frontier region and only 4 people are currently being treated. "Nothing suggests it will get worse," said Ian Simpson of the WHO. The WHO also dismissed rumors that the disease was being spread as biological warfare.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever in Pakistan is suspected to be the cause of 3 deaths. A female physician contracted the fever while taking care of a female patient brought in from Az Kashmir. She was given intravenous antiviral medication and support but developed uncontrolled hemorrhage from multiple sites and died.

2 people, including a staffer of Roznama Express Newspaper, have died due to [Crimean-] Congo virus in Quetta. The death toll from the virus in the city has now risen to 4 over the last 3 months. Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a widespread tick-borne viral disease that affects both wild and domestic animals.

11 cases of suspected CCHF have been admitted to the TB hospital in Quetta [Balochistan] since 1 Oct [2015]. All had a history of animal handling due to Eidul Azha [Islamic Feast of Sacrifice]. Of these, 3 of them died and one is still in critical condition. Samples for C CHF tests have been dispatched to NIH.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) was first reported in Pakistan in 1970. Outbreaks were reported in Baluchistan Province during the dry season in 1976, 1987, and 1994. Total cases for 2000 to 2001 are estimated at 115, with 34 to 39 deaths.

Hospitals in southwestern Pakistan put on high alert after 3 people from one family die of suspected Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever. The disease is spread by ticks from livestock and can be transmitted by infected people through their blood, saliva or droplets from sneezing. CCHF is endemic in this region.

3 people have died and 4 others have been admitted to hospital with suspected Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever in Baluchistan. The outbreak was not in Quetta, but is in rural areas. Outbreak is due to tick infestation of local livestock. About 30 per cent of people who contract the disease can die.

A 4th Pakistani has died of suspected Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV) infection in the southwestern city of Quetta. CCHF is a tick-borne virus stemming from livestock that is transmitted into open cuts and sores. It causes massive bleeding through the nose, mouth and ears.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV) has once again struck the interior parts of Baluchistan. 4 nomads including a baby have fallen                 prey to the disease in past few days. Medical facilities are not available in this remote region, and as a consequence the death toll may rise.

The patient was pronounced dead at Fatima Jinnah Chest and General Hospital in Quetta, taking the toll to 3 in 3 days. This is the 3rd reported fatal CCHF case from Balochistan that ProMED-mail has posted this year (2015) In addition, there is a recent report of 11 cases of suspected C CHF that have been admitted to the TB hospital in Queta [Balochistan] since 1 Oct 2015. Of these, 3 of them died, and one is still in critical condition. Samples for CCHf tests have been dispatched to NIH.

12-year-old girl hospitalized in Islamabad with CCHFV infection. Girl tested positive for Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus infection. Hospital administration closed the emergency ward for 2 days because of the presence of the patient. The girl was moved to the Pakistan Institute of Medical Sciences.

A 19-year-old man died from Congo fever at Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre (JPMC) on [Mon 1 Apr 2019], after which the death toll due to the fever mounted to 3 this year [2019]. CCHF is a tick-borne viral disease that is mainly contracted by people who deal with cattle and livestock. The symptoms of Congo virus include backache, joint pain, pain in the abdomen, high fever and bleeding from any part of the body.

7 members of a family suspected of having been infected were taken to Islamabad for specialized treatment, adding that one of them perished on the way. The victims were suffering from fever and hematuria and developed hemorrhagic spots on their bodies. Doctors say its onset is sudden with symptoms including headache, high pain, joint pain, stomach pain, vomiting and flushed face.

From 1 Jan 2013 to 9 Jun 2013, a total of 16 suspected cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) were reported from Pakistan. In 2012, the country faced a similar outbreak of CCHF with 61 suspected cases, including 17 deaths (case-fatality rate 27.8 percent) reported from the disease. The virus is transmitted to people from ticks and livestock animals.

From 1 Jan 2013 to 9 Jun 2013, a total of 16 suspected cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) were reported from Pakistan. In 2012, the country faced a similar outbreak of CCHF with 61 suspected cases, including 17 deaths (case-fatality rate 27.8 percent) reported from the disease. The virus is transmitted to people from ticks and livestock animals.

place: Haz?ra Division, North West Frontier Province, Pakistan
summary: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has claimed the lives of 2 people hailing from Havelian, a suburb of Abbottabad. An emergency meeting, headed by the Hazara commissioner, has alerted the district administrations of all the six districts and Health and Livestock Departments to take the remedial steps.

place: Haz?ra Division, North West Frontier Province, Pakistan
summary: A man from Abbottabad has died of Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) at the Pakistan Institute of Medical Sciences. His father and brother have been admitted to the hospital after succumbing to the same tick-borne zoonotic viral disease. One of the deceased's brothers had already lost his life to CCHF, which, according to the WHO, has a high fatality rate (10-40 per cent)

Four butchers died after being infected with Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus [CCHF] virus in September 2013. People in areas of Punjab, K-P and Balochistan have been exposed to the deadly virus. People think that because of its name, CCHF virus cannot be found in Pakistan, which is an ignorant assumption.

3 patients believed to have Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) died at Pims in April and May this year. CCHF virus is endemic in Africa, the Balkans, the Middle East, and Asia, in countries south of the 50th parallel north. Cases occur with some frequency in Pakistan.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has been reported in two cases in Pakistan. CCHF virus is transmitted to livestock via ticks. People usually acquire infection with this virus from infected livestock. No more cases were identified in the family or surrounding area.

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is endemic in the region of northwestern Pakistan/Afghanistan and neighboring Iran. Only the 2nd case was laboratory confirmed, but the bleeding symptoms of the others strongly suggested CCHF. The 3 patients are in addition to the 3 reported in previous posts (see ProMED-mail archives below)

An Afghan national has died of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) in a hospital in Quetta. According to the news report above, 9 patients have been admitted in the same hospital. So far in 2015, a total of 80 cases including 15 deaths have been reported. The source of the infection has not been mentioned in the report.

A patient with Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) passed away at a Peshawar hospital on Saturday. 11 Congo virus patients, including 6 from Afghanistan and one staffer, have been brought to HMC. Of these 11,  5 have died. CCHF is primarily transmitted to people from ticks and livestock.

The number of CCHF virus infections has increased from 8 on 12 Jul 2014 to 11 infections 4 days later, and now there are 12 on 22 Jul 2014. The virus can cause severe viral hemorrhagic fever outbreaks, with a case fatality rate of 10-40 per cent. It is not clear how many of these infections were acquired in Pakistan or in Afghanistan.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is endemic in Pakistan and Afghanistan. 12 patients have been brought to Hayatabad Medical Complex (HMC) hospital Peshawar so far this year, of whom 6 have died. 4 private rooms at HMC have been declared isolation units for CCHF patients and any individual brought to the casualty department with the symptoms will be admitted to the isolation ward.

At least 4 people, including a woman, were infected with the virus in the small village of Killi Blump near Meena Bazaar, located 40km from Zhob city. Western Pakistan and its border with Afghanistan are endemic areas for Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) virus. The virus is primarily transmitted to people from ticks and livestock animals.

A 62-year-old male patient was brought to the hospital 4 days ago from Choha Saiden Shah in Chakwal (Punjab) with a high fever. The hospital suspected it could be dengue fever and sent samples for testing to the National Institute of Health (NIH) The results showed that the patient was suffering from Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) CCHF is now endemic in Pakistan, and 40-60 cases and isolated outbreaks are reported.

A woman suffering from Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) died of the disease at Shifa International Hospital (SIH) here [Fri 6 Apr 2018]. This is the 1st confirmed case of CCHF in Pakistan this year. The case originated from southern Punjab region, with the history of animal handling in the case.

A 29-year-old man has been diagnosed with Congo-Crimean hemorrhagic fever. He has been admitted to an isolation ward at Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre. CCHF is a lethal viral infection that is transmitted to humans from animals. The National Institute of Health (NIH) has issued an advisory, calling for different stakeholders to take timely steps for the prevention and control of Congo virus.

Another patient of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) virus expired during treatment at hospital here [Quetta] on [Tue 13 Oct 2015], taking the death toll to 17 in the country. To date, 4 people have died of the dreadful Congo virus in Quetta after Eidul Azha [Festival of the Sacrifice], while the toll due to the virus across the country has climbed to 17. 3 Congo affected patients were under treatment at Fatima Jinnah Hospital Quetta and 9 in other hospitals across Pakistan.

At least 7 people have died of Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) in the Aga Khan Private hospital in Karachi, Pakistan. The hospital has confirmed the death of only 2 people, but sources say not less than 7 have died in the last few weeks. The cases are all those suffering from high fever and being kept in isolation.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a tick-borne viral disease, which can afflict domestic and wild animals and may also affect humans. The disease got its name after it was first described in Crimea in 1944 and later found in Congo, caused by the same pathogen. Nearly 50 cases of the disease have so far been reported from different parts of the country this year.

A patient admitted on suspicion of Congo virus [Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, CCHF] in Fatima Jinnah Chest Hospital Quetta passed away Saturday noon. In Pakistan, overall 11 cases of this virus have been reported in 2017, of which 4 patients recovered and 2 and one died from the confirmed and suspected virus, respectively.

More than 40 people have been diagnosed with hemorrhagic fever in Karachi. Doctors in Karachi have been ordered to take special protective measures. The disease can spread by massive bleeding, with which patients with the fever suffer. A woman doctor, who has died, was admitted to AKUH bleeding profusely.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) in various parts of Pakistan are continuing this year (2014) 2 deaths have been reported in Karachi, with a young butcher from the city's central district succumbing to the virus on 22 Aug [2014]. 16 CCHF cases had been reported just at Aga Khan University laboratories across Pakistan.

The 2nd Congo virus [Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever] case of the year [2014] recently surfaced in the city [Karachi, Sindh province]. Luckily, the patient is said to be in a stable condition. The history of the latest patient shows that he used to play in a ground located near a cattle pen. Health care providers fear that the situation seems very critical as 2 cases have surfaced within 15 days and thousands of animals are being brought to the city every day.

A 51-year-old man died in Karachi due to the deadly, tick-borne viral disease. This was the 3rd case reported in the city this year, with 2 of them fatal. The man's exposure may have been via tick bite or exposure to the blood of an infected animal.

2 young men and a 35-year-old woman in Karachi have Congo-Crimean haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) CCHF virus is a tickborne virus in the genus _Nairovirus_, family _Bunyaviridae. The virus can cause severe viral hemorrhagic fever outbreaks, with a case fatality rate of 10-40 per cent.

A 50-year-old resident of Chahcro, had been admitted to a private hospital in the city after his blood samples tested positive for the Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) virus. 2 deaths have been reported in Karachi, with a young butcher from the city's central district succumbing to the virus on [22 Aug 2014].

A man, a man, 38 years old, with co-morbidity (viral hepatitis C) from Jalalabad [Nangarhar province], Afghanistan, with a short history [4 days only] of high grade fever and bleeding from the mouth and nose, landed at Northwest General private hospital Peshawar [Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa province, Pakistan] on 5 May 2015. He was treated as a chronic liver disease patient and a splenectomy was planned to correct the thrombocytopenia. However, this patient was transferred to Maroof International Hospital Islamabad [Pakistan] on 7 May [2015] on the request of relatives, but against

A 35-year-old man hailing from Quetta died of the Congo Crimean Haemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) at a private hospital in Karachi on [Wed 13 Sep 2017]. Another Congo fever patient - a teenager from Queta - was admitted to the Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre's intensive care unit in critical condition on [Thu 14 Sep 2017], officials of the Sindh Health Department told The News. 4 people brought from Balochistan - all residents of Quetta's Satellite Town - for treatment of Congo virus have died at different hospitals in Karachi over the past 6 months. A highly contagious viral disease caused by a tick, Congo Crimean Hemorrhagen Fever

The man, aged 37, was admitted to a private hospital with a severe fever, shortness of breath and haemorrhage 2 days before he was pronounced dead by doctors on Saturday. "It was the 1st case of CCHF in Sindh in 2015," said an official in the provincial health department. The victim caught the viral disease through a tick found on animals.

A 45 year old man from the village Beyali, Mansehra, an animal trader, became ill with fever and loose motions [bowels?] on 8 May 2015. He was treated by local doctors in the village. On 17 May 2015, he was shifted to the Pakistan Institute of Medical Sciences Islamabad for further treatment, where he was kept in ICU. A sample for Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever [CCHF] serology was sent on [20? May 2015]. He expired on 21 May 2015 and the case was declared CCHF positive by the National Institute of Health on 24 May2015. The circumstances under which the patient acquired his CCH

A 13-year-old Afghan national is suspected to be infected with the Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever [CCHF], commonly known as Congo virus. The number of patients from Afghanistan arriving in the city for medical treatment has increased over the last 2 months. At least 9 suspected virus-carriers have been brought to the provincial capital [Peshawar] for treatment during the last two months.

A teenager from Quetta has contracted the Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) and is being treated in the isolation ward of the Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre. The CCHF is caused when a person comes into contact with the deadly virus that is found in ticks present on the bodies of cattle and some other animals. Quetta is a hub of the Congo virus, as several people contract the viral disease due to movement of cattle from Afghanistan.

Officials at Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre (JPMC) confirmed on [Fri 31 Aug 2018] a second patient from Quetta, Balochistan, was affected by Congo Crimean Hemorrhagic Fever [CCHF] adding that now 2 patients suffering from the disease are under treatment at the health facility.

A patient died at the Hayatabad Medical Complex here on Saturday [1 Aug 2015] from Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus [CCHFV]. There are 3 patients being treated at the hospital from the virus [infection]. The patient who died is from Afghanistan. It is not clear whether the other 2 patients are also from there or are from Pakistan.

2 new cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) have been diagnosed at a hospital in Peshawar, Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa. The patients are residents of 2 cities, Peshawar and Kohat. The source of the infection for the cases is not mentioned in the news report.

The Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) virus is endemic in Pakistan. Cases of CCHF occurred in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and in Sindh provinces this year (2015) and in various parts of Pakistan last year (2014) The 12-year-old is reported to be out of danger while the other patient is still in critical condition.

A patient, who had contracted Crimean-Congo viral haemorrhagic fever (CCHF), died in a Nishtar Hospital in Multan, Punjab. He probably acquired the infection via a tick bite or exposure to the blood of an infected animal. CCHF virus is a tickborne virus in the genus _Nairovirus_, family _Bunyaviridae. It can cause severe viral hemorrhagic fever outbreaks, with a case fatality rate of 10-40 percent.

A 50-year-old male patient from Balochistan province died of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) in a hospital in Multan, Punjab province. The source of infection and detailed clinical information about the deceased are not mentioned in the news report.Detailed information on the case from knowledgeable sources would be much appreciated. CCHF is endemic in Pakistan.

The Congo virus has spread through animal markets in Peshawar where livestock in large numbers have been brought ahead of Eidul Azha. Reports say that 9 people have already died after contracting the virus, which is almost invariably fatal. Those who are in frequent contact with animals, including the keepers of livestock, vets, poachers, are most at risk.

In Karachi, 2 more people with Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) were admitted to Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Center. The condition of one patient was reported critical. Nearly 50 cases of the disease have so far been reported from different parts of the country this year (2014) There have been 19 suspected cases with 6 deaths reported in Karachi so far in 2014 (see the archives cited below)

Two more people with Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) were admitted to Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Center. The condition of one patient was reported as critical. According to the health officials, 6 people have died due to CCHF in 2014, while 19 patients have been reported from different areas of the city.

A child from Balochistan died with suspected Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) in a hospital in Multan, Punjab. The child was being treated at the hospital since 23 Sep 2015. The source of the infection is not mentioned in the news report. It would be interesting to know if the child was related to or came into contact with the deceased person.

A 7-year-old boy from Barkhan district, Balochistan, died from Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever. The virus is endemic in Pakistan. Cases of CCHF have occurred in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Punjab, and Sindh provinces this year and in various parts of Pakistan last year.

A patient, AK, son of H, resident of Quetta Baluchistan, was brought to the emergency department with history of fever and nasal blood for 2 days. He was diagnosed Congo through lab reports. The patient was exposed having contact history with animals. A total of 8 Congo-infected patients have been reported in the hospital so far, out of which 5 were cured and discharged.

3 more suspected Congo virus patients admitted to Quetta's Fatima Jinnah Hospital diagnosed with disease. This took the tally of confirmed Congo virus cases to 25 in Balochistan this year [2019]. The virus has also claimed 5 lives, according to Dr Sadiq, the head of the ward at the hospital where Congo fever patients are treated.

Another patient died of the Congo virus in Quetta's Fatima Jinnah Hospital. So far, 47 people suspected to have the disease have been admitted to the hospital. A total of 6 people have died from the disease. Public health advice should focus on several aspects. Reducing the risk of tick-to-human transmission.

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever was first seen in Rawalpindi, where a 25-year-old female doctor was the first person to die. The outbreak was extremely short and incubation period was very short. The first patient to die was a female doctor (25 years old), who died on the 'Eid of the Sacrifice'

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) was confirmed in 2 under-treatment patients in Civil Hospital Karachi [Sindh province] Last year, 17 cases of CCHF were reported in the country, with 9 of them in Sindh province. They probably acquired the infection via a tick bite or exposure to the blood of an infected animal.

Congo virus has killed at least 11 patients in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province only owing to a drastic lack of medical facilities. At least 25 Congo virus-positive patients from Peshawar, Swabi, Kohat and Dir were brought to Hyatabad Medical Complex in critical condition in last 5 months.

2 brothers suspected to be suffering from Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) died in Rawalpindi. CCHF virus was first isolated in 1970 from ticks from the Changa Manga forest, Lahore district, and from Hunza, Gilgit Agency. In humans, the disease appears suddenly with symptoms similar to those of influenza.

A patient of Congo virus expired during treatment at Peshawar's Hayatabad Medical Complex [Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province], ARY News reported on Tuesday. The fresh death increased the death toll by Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) in Pakistan, to 24. The incidence of CCHF in Pakistan is widespread.

A patient died of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever in Rawalpindi General Hospital. The doctor who first attended to the patient also developed symptoms of the virus. The patient was placed in isolation to avoid further transmission. The affected area has been surveyed, and the agriculture and livestock department has developed a plan to spray cattle sheds.

A new case of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has been reported from Karachi, bringing the total number of cases to 4 this year (2015) The patient is undergoing treatment at a hospital and is recovering. However, the report does not mention the source of the infection. As many as 4 patients have surfaced so far in Pakistan.

A 49 year old victim was diagnosed with Congo virus and admitted to Sindh Employees Social Security Hospital, near Nipa Chowrangi. It is the 6th case of Congo virus in the country and the 2nd case from Sindh, he said. A doctor and cattle-handler from Bahawalpur and an Afghan national have died in different hospitals in Karachi within a month.

A patient at Holy Family Hospital (HFH) [Rawalpindi, Punjab] tested positive for Congo fever on [Sat 30 Jul 2016]. The 62-year-old man was brought to the hospital 4 days ago from Choha Saiden Shah in Chakwal with a high fever. The hospital suspected it could be dengue fever and sent samples for testing to the National Institute of Health. The results showed that he was suffering from Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF)

A Congo Crimean haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) patient died on [Sat 30 Jul 2016] in a private hospital of the city. Dr S, a surgeon in Bahawalpur Victoria Hospital, was reportedly admitted in the hospital in July 2016 with 5-6 days history of symptoms of fever, sore throat and diarrhoea. He was shifted to Agha Khan University Hospital, Karachi and was diagnosed as CCHF positive on [28 Jul 2016].

A 13-year old boy from Khara died of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) on 30 Jul 2016. He is the 3rd CCHF patient to die in 2 weeks. A surgeon at the Victoria Hospital in Bahawalpur, Dr S.A.S. and a student nurse at District Headquarters Hospital Lodhran, died on 17 Jul.

The patient was admitted in the hospital a few days ago in suspicion of Congo virus. He was in special ward for treatment while today doctors have confirmed his death. Health experts advised the citizens to take special preventive measures to protect from carrying Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF)

One man was diagnosed with dengue plus Crimean-Congo virus [CCHFv] in Karachi. Cases of CCHF occurred in Sindh provinces this year (2015) and in various parts of Pakistan last year (2014) There is a significant risk of infection for those involved in slaughtering the animals and others in contact with the bodily fluids of those animals.

A total of 20 people died because of Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) in the country this year [2016] including 12 patients from Balochistan, 5 from Karachi while 5 suspected patients were registered in Hayatabad Medical Complex in Peshawar. The latest victim, a woman, who was brought from Afghanistan for medical treatment, died of the virus at Fatima Jinnah TB Sanatorium Hospital in Quetta.

A 22-year-old man from Bahawalpur had brought sacrificial animals in the city to sell ahead of Eidul Azha [or Eid al-Adha, Festival of the Sacrifice] died at the Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre (JPMC) after being inflicted with the Congo fever. Health experts have warned that Congo viral disease might take epidemic proportions in coming weeks. They have asked authorities concerned to devise a strategy for screening and vaccination of animals. Wearing gloves and other protective clothing is recommended.

Two more Congo virus cases were reported as 2 patients were found affected with Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) today. Congo virus has claimed 19 lives across the country including 5 in Karachi [Sindh province], 12 in Quetta [Balochistan province] and 2 in Bahawalpur [Punjab province] this year [2016]. Congo virus is a viral disease that commonly spreads by ticks found on hairy animals.

The number of deaths caused due to the Congo [Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever] virus has increased to 5 in Sindh. The virus is carried by ticks that inhabit the skin of various animals. When these ticks bite humans or enter the bloodstream, the body gets infected by the Congo virus.

A 49 year old man from Afghanistan succumbed to the deadly viral disease at the Aga Khan University Hospital (AKUH) on Sunday. The man had been brought from Kabul by road and admitted to the private hospital on 21 Aug [2016], his nephew said. The fatality occurred amid deaths of dozens of sacrificial animals in mysterious circumstances at the cattle market set up along Super Highway.

A woman and a man died of Congo-Crimean haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) in the city [Karachi] last week. The city has recorded 6 CCHF cases this year [2015]. The previous 4 patients were successfully treated. Exposure to ticks during the 2nd largest Muslim festival of Eidul Azha in September 2015 is suspected to be the source of infection of these cases.

A 12-year-old boy was diagnosed with Congo virus [Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus, CCHFv] today [3 Sep 2016], taking the total number affected in Balochistan to 27 with 10 dead so far. The total number of people who were admitted to different hospitals for scans for the fatal virus stands at 94, out of which 27 were found positive.

One of the 3 teaching hospitals in [Rawalpindi, Punjab province], Holy Family Hospital [HFH], registered as many as 4 suspects of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) within last 10 days of which one female has been confirmed positive for the disease. The registration of 4 suspects and confirmation of a patient has strengthened doubts that the population in the region may face a possible spike of CCHF ahead of Eidul Azha.

The first Congo virus [Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, CCHF] case has been reported in Faisalabad [Punjab] on [Sun 18 Sep 2016]. The 20-year-old patient RA was shifted in Civil hospital's private ward 3 days ago. According to doctors, the condition of the patient is critical as the number of his platelets has decreased to 5000. On the other hand, the death toll from Congo virus in Quetta [Balochistan] has reached 13 after 1 more patient died.

A 35-year-old woman was admitted at Nishtar Medical Hospital on Saturday [17 Sep 2016] with symptoms of Congo fever. The total number of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) cases from Pakistan as of 22 Sep 2016 (personal communication) is 72 and the distribution by province is 129 / 14 / 9.

At least 6 people have died in Punjab of the Congo virus, raising the death toll to 24 in the country in 2016. Health officials told The Express Tribune at least 129 patients have been admitted to government-run hospitals of which 12 have tested positive for Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF)

Up to 3 patients have died in Peshawar due to Congo virus in this year. A 36-year-old woman, a resident of Hyderabad, died of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever. The patient was brought to the hospital's Emergency Department in the night hours and was later moved to an isolation ward for treatment, where she died after an hour. This was the 3rd death reported in the institution.

A senior registrar of the Bahawal Victoria Hospital (BVH) was put on ventilator after Karachi's Aga Khan Hospital laboratory reports confirmed Congo virus. The virus has been confirmed almost a fortnight [2 weeks] after Dr S went down with 'high-grade fever' A house officer who works in the same ward under Dr S, also underwent tests in Karachi on Friday [29 Jul 2016] (the result is awaited)

A veterinary doctor and resident of Gulistan-e-Jauhar, has been brought to the emergency department in serious condition and he has been confirmed with Congo Crimean viral infection. Congo fever is a highly lethal viral disease and it has claimed 9 lives so far in Karachi alone this year [2016] Overall, 71 patients have been diagnosed with Congo fever in the city this year.

19 suspected cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF), including 4 deaths, have been reported from Nishter Hospital Multan. 11 cases were negative, and 3 recovered from the disease. There is an urgent need to improve awareness among the health care community to diagnose cases.

A suspected case of CCHF admitted in Multan [Punjab province] notified on [15 Mar 2017] in south Punjab. A case response is in the process of execution right now, including contact tracing, quarantine, and use of PPE [personal protective equipment] as the patient is still admitted in ward 27, Nishter Hospital Multan. This case is the 1st laboratory confirmed case in Pakistan in 2017.

3 members of the same family -- all of them suspected of suffering from Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) -- are currently under observation at the Pakistan Institute of Medical Sciences. A relative of the suspected patients recently died of CCHF; family history warranted that the 3 be ruled out for the disease. The blood samples of the victims have been sent to the National Institute of Health for verification.

A new case of Congo virus [Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus] has been confirmed in Kohlu area of Balochistan. The patient remains under treatment at the hospital and has been declared to be out of danger. At least 30 cases of the virus were detected in the province during 2016. The disease is essentially asymptomatic in animals and poses a threat to people from across the population.

As many as 15 staff members including doctors, nurses and paramedics at a private medical facility, Maroof International Hospital, have been under observation after handling a patient who died of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) A 30-year-old male patient was brought to a healthcare facility in Peshawar from Afghanistan last week where he was initially treated for liver failure. The patient was given antiviral treatment and immunoglobulin, but his condition became critical, and he continued to bleed inside his lungs and was drowning in his own blood.

Four days after a suspected outbreak claimed 5 lives in Karak, authorities are still clueless as to what exactly the disease is. Some suspect it to be an outbreak of Acute Watery Diarrhea (AWD) while others believe that it is a strain of the Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF)

place: Islamabad City, Islamabad Capital Territory, Pakistan
summary: The patient, who comes from Sara-e-Naurang in Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa, is currently under treatment in the isolation ward of medical ward 2 at PIMS. The patient is involved in animal handling and slaughter, which is a high risk group for the disease. The disease of Congo is contracted from animals to humans though it can lead to death.

Patient brought to the Pakistan Institute of Medical Sciences (PIMS) for treatment of hepatitis on [Sun 4 Jun 2017], has been confirmed by the National Institute of Health as suffering from Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) The patient, who comes from Sara-e-Naurang in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, is currently under treatment in the isolation ward of medical ward 2 at PIMS.

One case has been laboratory confirmed for CCHF while the results are awaited for the 2nd case. The patient belongs to Kalakahar, Chakwal in Punjab. She was admitted with high grade fever, body-aches and hemorrhagic manifestations. She had a few domestic animals at home. The case has a history of contact with domestic livestock and presented with the typical clinical features of CCHF.

The 1st Congo virus [CCHFv] case was reported at the Allied Hospital here. The CCHF virus is tick borne and can cause severe viral hemorrhagic fever outbreaks. A woman suspected of suffering from Crimean-Congo virus was admitted to the Holy Family Hospital (HFH) on Tuesday [30 Jun 2015]. Patient undergoing treatment at one of the 3 teaching hospitals in town, Holy Family Hospital, has been tested positive for Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) CCHF is caused by Nairovirus of the Bunyaviridae family transmitted to humans by the bite of Hyalomma tick found on the skin of animals including goat and sheep.

Two people including a woman died of Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF), commonly known as Congo virus. Balochistan province has been endemic for CCHF for many years, and sporadic cases are reported every year, particularly between May and September/October.

A 23-year-old man with Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) was admitted to one of its isolation wards. CCHF is a tick-borne, potentially lethal viral disease with 30-40 per cent mortality rate. The patient's condition was critical due to extremely low platelets and total leucocytes counts.

A 25-year-old man died at Jinnah hospital in Karachi. The man was a resident of Mehmoodabad [Mahmudabad, Malir district] and was brought to the hospital 2 days ago. So far, 10 CCHF patients have died in the city -- 3 at JPMC, 7 at private health facilities.

Congo virus has been detected in Booni Chitral district after a butcher of Afghan nationality has been tested positive. The city's 1st case in 2019 of Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF), commonly known as Congo virus, was reported. The patient was identified as 35-year-old [TF], resident of Orangi Town. She is currently under treatment at an isolated ward of the Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre.

Another case of Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF), commonly known as Congo virus, has been reported in Karachi. CCHF is a lethal disease with 40 per cent mortality rate. The disease is caused when a person comes in contact with an infected animal, which has parasitic ticks on its body.

Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has killed 13 people in western Herat province this year. Symptoms may include fever, muscle pains, headache, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding into the skin. The CCHF virus is typically spread by tick bites or contact with livestock carrying the disease.

Six new cases of Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) were reported in the west region, bringing the total numbers of CCHF cases to 79 in 2017. 17 people lost their lives. The virus has been observed in over 30 countries, including in Africa, Asia, the Middle East, and southeastern Europe.
